subject: Re: how do we promote a phonemic/phonetic writing sytem for english
msgSnippet: ... I think that his is what this group is about. Look at Kingsley Read s Quickscript manual. ... phonemic ... but ... I m sure that there is an Esperanto
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "satnordameriko"
<satnordameriko@y...> wrote:
> either through a new writing sytem and/or a modification of the
> existing Roman one where each sound is represented either by it's
> own symbol and/or a consistent set of symbols (sometimes doubled?)
> if using traditional Roman script
>

I think that his is what this group is about. Look at Kingsley Read's
Quickscript manual.

> Evidently Spanish in 1713 changed it's writing system to be
phonemic
> (albeit not perfectly) unlike English
>
> and there's been various attempts at doing this with english
> (Deseret, Shavian, Read, (and one I can't remember the title for
but
> modified Roman script), I.T.E. etc)
>
> if english is going to the defacto lingua franca (I would prefer
> something like Esperanto instead given it's simplicity), then we
> need to figure out a way to not only make it easier to use (i.e.-
> phonetic/phonemic), but also in a way that we can popularize.
>

I'm sure that there is an Esperanto group for you. I think Radio Cuba
still broadcasts the news in Esperanto.

But if you think that Esperanto is the ultimate and switching to it
reasonable then why not go all the way and really go for a wholly
rational language? Since Esperanto is radically and wholly european it
has some resistance among those who see a problem with that. So
consider a 'neutral' language. Go look at Lojban.
